column48: Patient PBMCs were thawed and washed twice with PBS containing 0.1% BSA and 5 mM EDTA (PBS + BSA + EDTA). Cells were then incubated with anti-CD16/CD32 (clone 93, Biolegend) to prevent nonspecific binding. Single-cell suspensions were stained with combinations of antibodies against CD3 (clone UCHT1), CD4 (clone OKT4), CD5 (clone UCHT2), CD8 (clone SK1), CD14 (clone M5E2), CD19 (clone HIB19), CD20 (clone 2H7), CD24 (clone ML5), CD25 (clone BC96), CD27 (clone O323), CD38 (clone HB-7), CD45RA (clone HI100), CD45RO (clone 304218), CD56 (clone NCAM16.2), CD127 (clone A019D5), CD197 (CCR7, clone G043H7), CD223 (LAG3, clone 11C3C65), CD279 (PD-1, clone EH12.2H7), CD366 (Tim3, clone F38-2E2) and DAPI viability dye (all from Biolegend) for 30 min at 4 °C followed by two washes with PBS + BSA + EDTA. Cells were either acquired with a LSRFortessa (BD) cell analyzer or sort-purified with a MoFlo Astrois (Beckman Coulter). Data analysis was performed with FlowJo (Tree Star) software. We obtained whole blood from three healthy donors with informed consent, and isolated PBMCs through Ficoll-Paque density gradient centrifugation and stored them in liquid nitrogen. Following sample thawing, up to ten million cells were incubated with anti-CD16/CD32 (clone 93, Biolegend) to prevent nonspecific binding. Single-cell suspensions were stained with antibodies against CD3 (clone UCTH1), CD4 (clone OKT4), CD8 (clone SK1), CD19 (clone HIB19), CD20 (clone 2H7), CD24 (clone ML5), CD27 (clone M-T271), CD38 (clone HB-7), IgD (clone 1A6-2) and fixable Zombie Red viability dye (all from BioLegend) for 30 min at 4 °C followed by two washes with PBS + BSA + EDTA. Sorting was conducted using a Sony SH800 cell sorter, pre-gated on live singlet lymphocytes before sorting cell subpopulations as follows

column2: ATAC-seq on PBMCs from donor ND-1, Bcell
column9: PBMCs_healthy donor_Bcell
column12: All patients were diagnosed and treated and diagnosed according to the revised guidelines of the International Workshop Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia/National Cancer Institute. Patients were recruited through clinical trial NCT01804686, aimed at studying the long-term effect of PCI-32765 (ibrutinib) and reflect the clinical and biological heterogeneity of the disease. The study was approved by the ethics committees of the contributing institutions (Semmelweis University and Medical University of Vienna). Informed consent was obtained from all participants.
column14: Chromatin accessibility mapping was performed using the ATAC-seq method as previously described (Corces et al, Nature Genetics, 2016), with minor adaptations. In each experiment, a maximum of 50,000 sorted cells were pelleted by centrifuging for 5 min at 4 °C at 300 x g. After centrifugation, the pellet was carefully resuspended in the transposase reaction mix (12.5 µl 2xTD buffer, 2 µl TDE1 (Illumina) and 10.25 µl nuclease-free water, 0.25 µl 5% Digitonin (Sigma)) for 30 min at 37 °C. Following DNA purification with the MinElute kit eluting in 11 µl, 1 µl of the eluted DNA was used in a quantitative PCR (qPCR) reaction to estimate the optimum number of amplification cycles. Library amplification was followed by SPRI size selection to exclude fragments larger than 1,200 bp. DNA concentration was measured with a Qubit fluorometer (Life Technologies). Library amplification was performed using custom Nextera primers (Buenrostro et al, Nature Methods 2013). The libraries were sequenced by the Biomedical Sequencing Facility at CeMM using the Illumina HiSeq 4000 platform and the 50-bp single-end configuration.
column15: ATAC-seq on PBMCs from donor ND-1, Bcell, ATAC-seq_ND-1_Bcell
column16: Base calls provided by the Illumina Realtime Analysis software were converted into BAM format using Illumina2bam and demultiplexed using BamIndexDecoder (https://github.com/wtsi-npg/illumina2bam), Sequenced reads were trimmed for adaptor sequences, Reads were mapped to hg19 whole genome using bowtie2 v2.2.4 with the –very-sensitive parameter, Duplicate reads were marked and removed with picard tools version 1.118, Peaks for ATAC-seq samples were called with MACS2 version 2.1.1.20160309 using the “–nomodel” and “–extsize 147” parameters
column20: CeMM Research Center for Molecular Medicine of the Austrian Academy of Sciences
column33: ATAC-seq on PBMCs from donor ND-1, Bcell
column47: Processed data files in bigWig format contain chromatin accessibility profiles and narrowPeak files contain peak calls for each sample
column48: T cell (CD3+), total B cell (CD19+, CD20+), naive B cell (CD27-, IgD+), natural effector B cell (CD27+, IgD+), and memory B cell (CD27+, IgD-).

After centrifugation, the pellet was carefully resuspended in the transposase reaction mix (12.5 µl 2xTD buffer, 2 µl TDE1 (Illumina) and 10.25 µl nuclease-free water, 0.25 µl 5% Digitonin (Sigma)) for 30 min at 37 °C. Following DNA purification with the MinElute kit eluting in 11 µl, 1 µl of the eluted DNA was used in a quantitative PCR (qPCR) reaction to estimate the optimum number of amplification cycles. Library amplification was followed by SPRI size selection to exclude fragments larger than 1,200 bp. DNA concentration was measured with a Qubit fluorometer (Life Technologies). Library amplification was performed using custom Nextera primers (Buenrostro et al, Nature Methods 2013). The libraries were sequenced by the Biomedical Sequencing Facility at CeMM using the Illumina HiSeq 4000 platform and the 50-bp single-end configuration.
column15: ATAC-seq on PBMCs from donor ND-2, NaiveBcell, ATAC-seq_ND-2_NaiveBcell
column16: Base calls provided by the Illumina Realtime Analysis software were converted into BAM format using Illumina2bam and demultiplexed using BamIndexDecoder (https://github.com/wtsi-npg/illumina2bam), Sequenced reads were trimmed for adaptor sequences, Reads were mapped to hg19 whole genome using bowtie2 v2.2.4 with the –very-sensitive parameter, Duplicate reads were marked and removed with picard tools version 1.118, Peaks for ATAC-seq samples were called with MACS2 version 2.1.1.20160309 using the “–nomodel” and “–extsize 147” parameters
column20: CeMM Research Center for Molecular Medicine of the Austrian Academy of Sciences
column33: ATAC-seq on PBMCs from donor ND-2, NaiveBcell
column47: Processed data files in bigWig format contain chromatin accessibility profiles and narrowPeak files contain peak calls for each sample
column48: T cell (CD3+), total B cell (CD19+, CD20+), naive B cell (CD27-, IgD+), natural effector B cell (CD27+, IgD+), and memory B cell (CD27+, IgD-).

After centrifugation, the pellet was carefully resuspended in the transposase reaction mix (12.5 µl 2xTD buffer, 2 µl TDE1 (Illumina) and 10.25 µl nuclease-free water, 0.25 µl 5% Digitonin (Sigma)) for 30 min at 37 °C. Following DNA purification with the MinElute kit eluting in 11 µl, 1 µl of the eluted DNA was used in a quantitative PCR (qPCR) reaction to estimate the optimum number of amplification cycles. Library amplification was followed by SPRI size selection to exclude fragments larger than 1,200 bp. DNA concentration was measured with a Qubit fluorometer (Life Technologies). Library amplification was performed using custom Nextera primers (Buenrostro et al, Nature Methods 2013). The libraries were sequenced by the Biomedical Sequencing Facility at CeMM using the Illumina HiSeq 4000 platform and the 50-bp single-end configuration.
column15: ATAC-seq on PBMCs from patient CLL1 on day 0 of ibrutinib treatment, Bcell cells, ATAC-seq_CLL1_0d_Bcell
column16: Base calls provided by the Illumina Realtime Analysis software were converted into BAM format using Illumina2bam and demultiplexed using BamIndexDecoder (https://github.com/wtsi-npg/illumina2bam), Sequenced reads were trimmed for adaptor sequences, Reads were mapped to hg19 whole genome using bowtie2 v2.2.4 with the –very-sensitive parameter, Duplicate reads were marked and removed with picard tools version 1.118, Peaks for ATAC-seq samples were called with MACS2 version 2.1.1.20160309 using the “–nomodel” and “–extsize 147” parameters
column20: CeMM Research Center for Molecular Medicine of the Austrian Academy of Sciences
column33: ATAC-seq on PBMCs from patient CLL1 on day 0 of ibrutinib treatment, Bcell cells
column47: Processed data files in bigWig format contain chromatin accessibility profiles and narrowPeak files contain peak calls for each sample
column48: T cell (CD3+), total B cell (CD19+, CD20+), naive B cell (CD27-, IgD+), natural effector B cell (CD27+, IgD+), and memory B cell (CD27+, IgD-).

column33: ATAC-seq on PBMCs from patient CLL1 on day 120 of ibrutinib treatment, CD4 cells, replicate 1
column47: Processed data files in bigWig format contain chromatin accessibility profiles and narrowPeak files contain peak calls for each sample
column48: T cell (CD3+), total B cell (CD19+, CD20+), naive B cell (CD27-, IgD+), natural effector B cell (CD27+, IgD+), and memory B cell (CD27+, IgD-).

column2: ATAC-seq on PBMCs from patient CLL1 on day 120 of ibrutinib treatment, CD4 cells, replicate 1
column9: PBMCs_CLL patient_day 120 of ibrutinib treatment_CD4 cells
column12: All patients were diagnosed and treated and diagnosed according to the revised guidelines of the International Workshop Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia/National Cancer Institute. Patients were recruited through clinical trial NCT01804686, aimed at studying the long-term effect of PCI-32765 (ibrutinib) and reflect the clinical and biological heterogeneity of the disease. The study was approved by the ethics committees of the contributing institutions (Semmelweis University and Medical University of Vienna). Informed consent was obtained from all participants.
column14: Chromatin accessibility mapping was performed using the ATAC-seq method as previously described (Corces et al, Nature Genetics, 2016), with minor adaptations. In each experiment, a maximum of 50,000 sorted cells were pelleted by centrifuging for 5 min at 4 °C at 300 x g. After centrifugation, the pellet was carefully resuspended in the transposase reaction mix (12.5 µl 2xTD buffer, 2 µl TDE1 (Illumina) and 10.25 µl nuclease-free water, 0.25 µl 5% Digitonin (Sigma)) for 30 min at 37 °C. Following DNA purification with the MinElute kit eluting in 11 µl, 1 µl of the eluted DNA was used in a quantitative PCR (qPCR) reaction to estimate the optimum number of amplification cycles. Library amplification was followed by SPRI size selection to exclude fragments larger than 1,200 bp. DNA concentration was measured with a Qubit fluorometer (Life Technologies). Library amplification was performed using custom Nextera primers (Buenrostro et al, Nature Methods 2013). The libraries were sequenced by the Biomedical Sequencing Facility at CeMM using the Illumina HiSeq 4000 platform and the 50-bp single-end configuration.

column14: Chromatin accessibility mapping was performed using the ATAC-seq method as previously described (Corces et al, Nature Genetics, 2016), with minor adaptations. In each experiment, a maximum of 50,000 sorted cells were pelleted by centrifuging for 5 min at 4 °C at 300 x g. After centrifugation, the pellet was carefully resuspended in the transposase reaction mix (12.5 µl 2xTD buffer, 2 µl TDE1 (Illumina) and 10.25 µl nuclease-free water, 0.25 µl 5% Digitonin (Sigma)) for 30 min at 37 °C. Following DNA purification with the MinElute kit eluting in 11 µl, 1 µl of the eluted DNA was used in a quantitative PCR (qPCR) reaction to estimate the optimum number of amplification cycles. Library amplification was followed by SPRI size selection to exclude fragments larger than 1,200 bp. DNA concentration was measured with a Qubit fluorometer (Life Technologies). Library amplification was performed using custom Nextera primers (Buenrostro et al, Nature Methods 2013). The libraries were sequenced by the Biomedical Sequencing Facility at CeMM using the Illumina HiSeq 4000 platform and the 50-bp single-end configuration.
column15: ATAC-seq on PBMCs from patient CLL1 on day 120 of ibrutinib treatment, CD8 cells, ATAC-seq_CLL1_120d_CD8
column16: Base calls provided by the Illumina Realtime Analysis software were converted into BAM format using Illumina2bam and demultiplexed using BamIndexDecoder (https://github.com/wtsi-npg/illumina2bam), Sequenced reads were trimmed for adaptor sequences, Reads were mapped to hg19 whole genome using bowtie2 v2.2.4 with the –very-sensitive parameter, Duplicate reads were marked and removed with picard tools version 1.118, Peaks for ATAC-seq samples were called with MACS2 version 2.1.1.20160309 using the “–nomodel” and “–extsize 147” parameters
column20: CeMM Research Center for Molecular Medicine of the Austrian Academy of Sciences
column33: ATAC-seq on PBMCs from patient CLL1 on day 120 of ibrutinib treatment, CD8 cells
column47: Processed data files in bigWig format contain chromatin accessibility profiles and narrowPeak files contain peak calls for each sample
column48: T cell (CD3+), total B cell (CD19+, CD20+), naive B cell (CD27-, IgD+), natural effector B cell (CD27+, IgD+), and memory B cell (CD27+, IgD-).

column16: Base calls provided by the Illumina Realtime Analysis software were converted into BAM format using Illumina2bam and demultiplexed using BamIndexDecoder (https://github.com/wtsi-npg/illumina2bam), Sequenced reads were trimmed for adaptor sequences, Reads were mapped to hg19 whole genome using bowtie2 v2.2.4 with the –very-sensitive parameter, Duplicate reads were marked and removed with picard tools version 1.118, Peaks for ATAC-seq samples were called with MACS2 version 2.1.1.20160309 using the “–nomodel” and “–extsize 147” parameters

column2: ATAC-seq on PBMCs from patient CLL1 on day 3 of ibrutinib treatment, NK cells
column9: PBMCs_CLL patient_day 3 of ibrutinib treatment_NK cells
column12: All patients were diagnosed and treated and diagnosed according to the revised guidelines of the International Workshop Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia/National Cancer Institute. Patients were recruited through clinical trial NCT01804686, aimed at studying the long-term effect of PCI-32765 (ibrutinib) and reflect the clinical and biological heterogeneity of the disease. The study was approved by the ethics committees of the contributing institutions (Semmelweis University and Medical University of Vienna). Informed consent was obtained from all participants.
column14: Chromatin accessibility mapping was performed using the ATAC-seq method as previously described (Corces et al, Nature Genetics, 2016), with minor adaptations. In each experiment, a maximum of 50,000 sorted cells were pelleted by centrifuging for 5 min at 4 °C at 300 x g. After centrifugation, the pellet was carefully resuspended in the transposase reaction mix (12.5 µl 2xTD buffer, 2 µl TDE1 (Illumina) and 10.25 µl nuclease-free water, 0.25 µl 5% Digitonin (Sigma)) for 30 min at 37 °C. Following DNA purification with the MinElute kit eluting in 11 µl, 1 µl of the eluted DNA was used in a quantitative PCR (qPCR) reaction to estimate the optimum number of amplification cycles. Library amplification was followed by SPRI size selection to exclude fragments larger than 1,200 bp. DNA concentration was measured with a Qubit fluorometer (Life Technologies). Library amplification was performed using custom Nextera primers (Buenrostro et al, Nature Methods 2013). The libraries were sequenced by the Biomedical Sequencing Facility at CeMM using the Illumina HiSeq 4000 platform and the 50-bp single-end configuration.

The study was approved by the ethics committees of the contributing institutions (Semmelweis University and Medical University of Vienna). Informed consent was obtained from all participants.
column14: Chromatin accessibility mapping was performed using the ATAC-seq method as previously described (Corces et al, Nature Genetics, 2016), with minor adaptations. In each experiment, a maximum of 50,000 sorted cells were pelleted by centrifuging for 5 min at 4 °C at 300 x g. After centrifugation, the pellet was carefully resuspended in the transposase reaction mix (12.5 µl 2xTD buffer, 2 µl TDE1 (Illumina) and 10.25 µl nuclease-free water, 0.25 µl 5% Digitonin (Sigma)) for 30 min at 37 °C. Following DNA purification with the MinElute kit eluting in 11 µl, 1 µl of the eluted DNA was used in a quantitative PCR (qPCR) reaction to estimate the optimum number of amplification cycles. Library amplification was followed by SPRI size selection to exclude fragments larger than 1,200 bp. DNA concentration was measured with a Qubit fluorometer (Life Technologies). Library amplification was performed using custom Nextera primers (Buenrostro et al, Nature Methods 2013). The libraries were sequenced by the Biomedical Sequencing Facility at CeMM using the Illumina HiSeq 4000 platform and the 50-bp single-end configuration.
column15: ATAC-seq on PBMCs from patient CLL2 on day 30 of ibrutinib treatment, Bcell cells, ATAC-seq_CLL2_30d_Bcell
column16: Base calls provided by the Illumina Realtime Analysis software were converted into BAM format using Illumina2bam and demultiplexed using BamIndexDecoder (https://github.com/wtsi-npg/illumina2bam), Sequenced reads were trimmed for adaptor sequences, Reads were mapped to hg19 whole genome using bowtie2 v2.2.4 with the –very-sensitive parameter, Duplicate reads were marked and removed with picard tools version 1.118, Peaks for ATAC-seq samples were called with MACS2 version 2.1.1.20160309 using the “–nomodel” and “–extsize 147” parameters
column20: CeMM Research Center for Molecular Medicine of the Austrian Academy of Sciences
column33: ATAC-seq on PBMCs from patient CLL2 on day 30 of ibrutinib treatment, Bcell cells
column47: Processed data files in bigWig format contain chromatin accessibility profiles and narrowPeak files contain peak calls for each sample
column48: T cell (CD3+), total B cell (CD19+, CD20+), naive B cell (CD27-, IgD+), natural effector B cell (CD27+, IgD+), and memory B cell (CD27+, IgD-).

column16: Base calls provided by the Illumina Realtime Analysis software were converted into BAM format using Illumina2bam and demultiplexed using BamIndexDecoder (https://github.com/wtsi-npg/illumina2bam), Sequenced reads were trimmed for adaptor sequences, Reads were mapped to hg19 whole genome using bowtie2 v2.2.4 with the –very-sensitive parameter, Duplicate reads were marked and removed with picard tools version 1.118, Peaks for ATAC-seq samples were called with MACS2 version 2.1.1.20160309 using the “–nomodel” and “–extsize 147” parameters
column20: CeMM Research Center for Molecular Medicine of the Austrian Academy of Sciences

column47: Processed data files in bigWig format contain chromatin accessibility profiles and narrowPeak files contain peak calls for each sample

column2: ATAC-seq on PBMCs from patient CLL2 on day 30 of ibrutinib treatment, CD4 cells
column9: PBMCs_CLL patient_day 30 of ibrutinib treatment_CD4 cells
column12: All patients were diagnosed and treated and diagnosed according to the revised guidelines of the International Workshop Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia/National Cancer Institute. Patients were recruited through clinical trial NCT01804686, aimed at studying the long-term effect of PCI-32765 (ibrutinib) and reflect the clinical and biological heterogeneity of the disease. The study was approved by the ethics committees of the contributing institutions (Semmelweis University and Medical University of Vienna). Informed consent was obtained from all participants.
column14: Chromatin accessibility mapping was performed using the ATAC-seq method as previously described (Corces et al, Nature Genetics, 2016), with minor adaptations. In each experiment, a maximum of 50,000 sorted cells were pelleted by centrifuging for 5 min at 4 °C at 300 x g. After centrifugation, the pellet was carefully resuspended in the transposase reaction mix (12.5 µl 2xTD buffer, 2 µl TDE1 (Illumina) and 10.25 µl nuclease-free water, 0.25 µl 5% Digitonin (Sigma)) for 30 min at 37 °C. Following DNA purification with the MinElute kit eluting in 11 µl, 1 µl of the eluted DNA was used in a quantitative PCR (qPCR) reaction to estimate the optimum number of amplification cycles. Library amplification was followed by SPRI size selection to exclude fragments larger than 1,200 bp. DNA concentration was measured with a Qubit fluorometer (Life Technologies). Library amplification was performed using custom Nextera primers (Buenrostro et al, Nature Methods 2013). The libraries were sequenced by the Biomedical Sequencing Facility at CeMM using the Illumina HiSeq 4000 platform and the 50-bp single-end configuration.

The study was approved by the ethics committees of the contributing institutions (Semmelweis University and Medical University of Vienna). Informed consent was obtained from all participants.
column14: Chromatin accessibility mapping was performed using the ATAC-seq method as previously described (Corces et al, Nature Genetics, 2016), with minor adaptations. In each experiment, a maximum of 50,000 sorted cells were pelleted by centrifuging for 5 min at 4 °C at 300 x g. After centrifugation, the pellet was carefully resuspended in the transposase reaction mix (12.5 µl 2xTD buffer, 2 µl TDE1 (Illumina) and 10.25 µl nuclease-free water, 0.25 µl 5% Digitonin (Sigma)) for 30 min at 37 °C. Following DNA purification with the MinElute kit eluting in 11 µl, 1 µl of the eluted DNA was used in a quantitative PCR (qPCR) reaction to estimate the optimum number of amplification cycles. Library amplification was followed by SPRI size selection to exclude fragments larger than 1,200 bp. DNA concentration was measured with a Qubit fluorometer (Life Technologies). Library amplification was performed using custom Nextera primers (Buenrostro et al, Nature Methods 2013). The libraries were sequenced by the Biomedical Sequencing Facility at CeMM using the Illumina HiSeq 4000 platform and the 50-bp single-end configuration.
column15: ATAC-seq on PBMCs from patient CLL2 on day 30 of ibrutinib treatment, CD8 cells, ATAC-seq_CLL2_30d_CD8
column16: Base calls provided by the Illumina Realtime Analysis software were converted into BAM format using Illumina2bam and demultiplexed using BamIndexDecoder (https://github.com/wtsi-npg/illumina2bam), Sequenced reads were trimmed for adaptor sequences, Reads were mapped to hg19 whole genome using bowtie2 v2.2.4 with the –very-sensitive parameter, Duplicate reads were marked and removed with picard tools version 1.118, Peaks for ATAC-seq samples were called with MACS2 version 2.1.1.20160309 using the “–nomodel” and “–extsize 147” parameters
column20: CeMM Research Center for Molecular Medicine of the Austrian Academy of Sciences
column33: ATAC-seq on PBMCs from patient CLL2 on day 30 of ibrutinib treatment, CD8 cells
column47: Processed data files in bigWig format contain chromatin accessibility profiles and narrowPeak files contain peak calls for each sample
column48: T cell (CD3+), total B cell (CD19+, CD20+), naive B cell (CD27-, IgD+), natural effector B cell (CD27+, IgD+), and memory B cell (CD27+, IgD-).

column16: Base calls provided by the Illumina Realtime Analysis software were converted into BAM format using Illumina2bam and demultiplexed using BamIndexDecoder (https://github.com/wtsi-npg/illumina2bam), Sequenced reads were trimmed for adaptor sequences, Reads were mapped to hg19 whole genome using bowtie2 v2.2.4 with the –very-sensitive parameter, Duplicate reads were marked and removed with picard tools version 1.118, Peaks for ATAC-seq samples were called with MACS2 version 2.1.1.20160309 using the “–nomodel” and “–extsize 147” parameters

column2: ATAC-seq on PBMCs from patient CLL2 on day 120 of ibrutinib treatment, CLL cells
column9: PBMCs_CLL patient_day 120 of ibrutinib treatment_CLL cells
column12: All patients were diagnosed and treated and diagnosed according to the revised guidelines of the International Workshop Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia/National Cancer Institute. Patients were recruited through clinical trial NCT01804686, aimed at studying the long-term effect of PCI-32765 (ibrutinib) and reflect the clinical and biological heterogeneity of the disease. The study was approved by the ethics committees of the contributing institutions (Semmelweis University and Medical University of Vienna). Informed consent was obtained from all participants.
column14: Chromatin accessibility mapping was performed using the ATAC-seq method as previously described (Corces et al, Nature Genetics, 2016), with minor adaptations. In each experiment, a maximum of 50,000 sorted cells were pelleted by centrifuging for 5 min at 4 °C at 300 x g. After centrifugation, the pellet was carefully resuspended in the transposase reaction mix (12.5 µl 2xTD buffer, 2 µl TDE1 (Illumina) and 10.25 µl nuclease-free water, 0.25 µl 5% Digitonin (Sigma)) for 30 min at 37 °C. Following DNA purification with the MinElute kit eluting in 11 µl, 1 µl of the eluted DNA was used in a quantitative PCR (qPCR) reaction to estimate the optimum number of amplification cycles. Library amplification was followed by SPRI size selection to exclude fragments larger than 1,200 bp. DNA concentration was measured with a Qubit fluorometer (Life Technologies). Library amplification was performed using custom Nextera primers (Buenrostro et al, Nature Methods 2013). The libraries were sequenced by the Biomedical Sequencing Facility at CeMM using the Illumina HiSeq 4000 platform and the 50-bp single-end configuration.

column14: Chromatin accessibility mapping was performed using the ATAC-seq method as previously described (Corces et al, Nature Genetics, 2016), with minor adaptations. In each experiment, a maximum of 50,000 sorted cells were pelleted by centrifuging for 5 min at 4 °C at 300 x g. After centrifugation, the pellet was carefully resuspended in the transposase reaction mix (12.5 µl 2xTD buffer, 2 µl TDE1 (Illumina) and 10.25 µl nuclease-free water, 0.25 µl 5% Digitonin (Sigma)) for 30 min at 37 °C. Following DNA purification with the MinElute kit eluting in 11 µl, 1 µl of the eluted DNA was used in a quantitative PCR (qPCR) reaction to estimate the optimum number of amplification cycles. Library amplification was followed by SPRI size selection to exclude fragments larger than 1,200 bp. DNA concentration was measured with a Qubit fluorometer (Life Technologies). Library amplification was performed using custom Nextera primers (Buenrostro et al, Nature Methods 2013). The libraries were sequenced by the Biomedical Sequencing Facility at CeMM using the Illumina HiSeq 4000 platform and the 50-bp single-end configuration.
column15: ATAC-seq on PBMCs from patient CLL2 on day 30 of ibrutinib treatment, NK cells, ATAC-seq_CLL2_30d_NK
column16: Base calls provided by the Illumina Realtime Analysis software were converted into BAM format using Illumina2bam and demultiplexed using BamIndexDecoder (https://github.com/wtsi-npg/illumina2bam), Sequenced reads were trimmed for adaptor sequences, Reads were mapped to hg19 whole genome using bowtie2 v2.2.4 with the –very-sensitive parameter, Duplicate reads were marked and removed with picard tools version 1.118, Peaks for ATAC-seq samples were called with MACS2 version 2.1.1.20160309 using the “–nomodel” and “–extsize 147” parameters
column20: CeMM Research Center for Molecular Medicine of the Austrian Academy of Sciences

column16: Base calls provided by the Illumina Realtime Analysis software were converted into BAM format using Illumina2bam and demultiplexed using BamIndexDecoder (https://github.com/wtsi-npg/illumina2bam), Sequenced reads were trimmed for adaptor sequences, Reads were mapped to hg19 whole genome using bowtie2 v2.2.4 with the –very-sensitive parameter, Duplicate reads were marked and removed with picard tools version 1.118, Peaks for ATAC-seq samples were called with MACS2 version 2.1.1.20160309 using the “–nomodel” and “–extsize 147” parameters
column20: CeMM Research Center for Molecular Medicine of the Austrian Academy of Sciences

column47: Processed data files in bigWig format contain chromatin accessibility profiles and narrowPeak files contain peak calls for each sample

column2: ATAC-seq on PBMCs from patient CLL4 on day 3 of ibrutinib treatment, CD4 cells
column9: PBMCs_CLL patient_day 3 of ibrutinib treatment_CD4 cells
column12: All patients were diagnosed and treated and diagnosed according to the revised guidelines of the International Workshop Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia/National Cancer Institute. Patients were recruited through clinical trial NCT01804686, aimed at studying the long-term effect of PCI-32765 (ibrutinib) and reflect the clinical and biological heterogeneity of the disease. The study was approved by the ethics committees of the contributing institutions (Semmelweis University and Medical University of Vienna). Informed consent was obtained from all participants.
column14: Chromatin accessibility mapping was performed using the ATAC-seq method as previously described (Corces et al, Nature Genetics, 2016), with minor adaptations. In each experiment, a maximum of 50,000 sorted cells were pelleted by centrifuging for 5 min at 4 °C at 300 x g. After centrifugation, the pellet was carefully resuspended in the transposase reaction mix (12.5 µl 2xTD buffer, 2 µl TDE1 (Illumina) and 10.25 µl nuclease-free water, 0.25 µl 5% Digitonin (Sigma)) for 30 min at 37 °C. Following DNA purification with the MinElute kit eluting in 11 µl, 1 µl of the eluted DNA was used in a quantitative PCR (qPCR) reaction to estimate the optimum number of amplification cycles. Library amplification was followed by SPRI size selection to exclude fragments larger than 1,200 bp. DNA concentration was measured with a Qubit fluorometer (Life Technologies). Library amplification was performed using custom Nextera primers (Buenrostro et al, Nature Methods 2013). The libraries were sequenced by the Biomedical Sequencing Facility at CeMM using the Illumina HiSeq 4000 platform and the 50-bp single-end configuration.

The study was approved by the ethics committees of the contributing institutions (Semmelweis University and Medical University of Vienna). Informed consent was obtained from all participants.
column14: Chromatin accessibility mapping was performed using the ATAC-seq method as previously described (Corces et al, Nature Genetics, 2016), with minor adaptations. In each experiment, a maximum of 50,000 sorted cells were pelleted by centrifuging for 5 min at 4 °C at 300 x g. After centrifugation, the pellet was carefully resuspended in the transposase reaction mix (12.5 µl 2xTD buffer, 2 µl TDE1 (Illumina) and 10.25 µl nuclease-free water, 0.25 µl 5% Digitonin (Sigma)) for 30 min at 37 °C. Following DNA purification with the MinElute kit eluting in 11 µl, 1 µl of the eluted DNA was used in a quantitative PCR (qPCR) reaction to estimate the optimum number of amplification cycles. Library amplification was followed by SPRI size selection to exclude fragments larger than 1,200 bp. DNA concentration was measured with a Qubit fluorometer (Life Technologies). Library amplification was performed using custom Nextera primers (Buenrostro et al, Nature Methods 2013). The libraries were sequenced by the Biomedical Sequencing Facility at CeMM using the Illumina HiSeq 4000 platform and the 50-bp single-end configuration.
column15: ATAC-seq on PBMCs from patient CLL4 on day 3 of ibrutinib treatment, CLL cells, ATAC-seq_CLL4_3d_CLL
column16: Base calls provided by the Illumina Realtime Analysis software were converted into BAM format using Illumina2bam and demultiplexed using BamIndexDecoder (https://github.com/wtsi-npg/illumina2bam), Sequenced reads were trimmed for adaptor sequences, Reads were mapped to hg19 whole genome using bowtie2 v2.2.4 with the –very-sensitive parameter, Duplicate reads were marked and removed with picard tools version 1.118, Peaks for ATAC-seq samples were called with MACS2 version 2.1.1.20160309 using the “–nomodel” and “–extsize 147” parameters
column20: CeMM Research Center for Molecular Medicine of the Austrian Academy of Sciences
column33: ATAC-seq on PBMCs from patient CLL4 on day 3 of ibrutinib treatment, CLL cells
column47: Processed data files in bigWig format contain chromatin accessibility profiles and narrowPeak files contain peak calls for each sample
column48: T cell (CD3+), total B cell (CD19+, CD20+), naive B cell (CD27-, IgD+), natural effector B cell (CD27+, IgD+), and memory B cell (CD27+, IgD-).

column16: Base calls provided by the Illumina Realtime Analysis software were converted into BAM format using Illumina2bam and demultiplexed using BamIndexDecoder (https://github.com/wtsi-npg/illumina2bam), Sequenced reads were trimmed for adaptor sequences, Reads were mapped to hg19 whole genome using bowtie2 v2.2.4 with the –very-sensitive parameter, Duplicate reads were marked and removed with picard tools version 1.118, Peaks for ATAC-seq samples were called with MACS2 version 2.1.1.20160309 using the “–nomodel” and “–extsize 147” parameters

column2: ATAC-seq on PBMCs from patient CLL5 on day 0 of ibrutinib treatment, Bcells, replicate 2
column9: PBMCs_CLL patient_day 0 of ibrutinib treatment_Bcells
column12: All patients were diagnosed and treated and diagnosed according to the revised guidelines of the International Workshop Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia/National Cancer Institute. Patients were recruited through clinical trial NCT01804686, aimed at studying the long-term effect of PCI-32765 (ibrutinib) and reflect the clinical and biological heterogeneity of the disease. The study was approved by the ethics committees of the contributing institutions (Semmelweis University and Medical University of Vienna). Informed consent was obtained from all participants.
column14: Chromatin accessibility mapping was performed using the ATAC-seq method as previously described (Corces et al, Nature Genetics, 2016), with minor adaptations. In each experiment, a maximum of 50,000 sorted cells were pelleted by centrifuging for 5 min at 4 °C at 300 x g. After centrifugation, the pellet was carefully resuspended in the transposase reaction mix (12.5 µl 2xTD buffer, 2 µl TDE1 (Illumina) and 10.25 µl nuclease-free water, 0.25 µl 5% Digitonin (Sigma)) for 30 min at 37 °C. Following DNA purification with the MinElute kit eluting in 11 µl, 1 µl of the eluted DNA was used in a quantitative PCR (qPCR) reaction to estimate the optimum number of amplification cycles. Library amplification was followed by SPRI size selection to exclude fragments larger than 1,200 bp. DNA concentration was measured with a Qubit fluorometer (Life Technologies). Library amplification was performed using custom Nextera primers (Buenrostro et al, Nature Methods 2013). The libraries were sequenced by the Biomedical Sequencing Facility at CeMM using the Illumina HiSeq 4000 platform and the 50-bp single-end configuration.

Patients were recruited through clinical trial NCT01804686, aimed at studying the long-term effect of PCI-32765 (ibrutinib) and reflect the clinical and biological heterogeneity of the disease. The study was approved by the ethics committees of the contributing institutions (Semmelweis University and Medical University of Vienna). Informed consent was obtained from all participants.
column14: Chromatin accessibility mapping was performed using the ATAC-seq method as previously described (Corces et al, Nature Genetics, 2016), with minor adaptations. In each experiment, a maximum of 50,000 sorted cells were pelleted by centrifuging for 5 min at 4 °C at 300 x g. After centrifugation, the pellet was carefully resuspended in the transposase reaction mix (12.5 µl 2xTD buffer, 2 µl TDE1 (Illumina) and 10.25 µl nuclease-free water, 0.25 µl 5% Digitonin (Sigma)) for 30 min at 37 °C. Following DNA purification with the MinElute kit eluting in 11 µl, 1 µl of the eluted DNA was used in a quantitative PCR (qPCR) reaction to estimate the optimum number of amplification cycles. Library amplification was followed by SPRI size selection to exclude fragments larger than 1,200 bp. DNA concentration was measured with a Qubit fluorometer (Life Technologies). Library amplification was performed using custom Nextera primers (Buenrostro et al, Nature Methods 2013). The libraries were sequenced by the Biomedical Sequencing Facility at CeMM using the Illumina HiSeq 4000 platform and the 50-bp single-end configuration.
column15: ATAC-seq on PBMCs from patient CLL5 on day 30 of ibrutinib treatment, Bcell cells, ATAC-seq_CLL5_30d_Bcell
column16: Base calls provided by the Illumina Realtime Analysis software were converted into BAM format using Illumina2bam and demultiplexed using BamIndexDecoder (https://github.com/wtsi-npg/illumina2bam), Sequenced reads were trimmed for adaptor sequences, Reads were mapped to hg19 whole genome using bowtie2 v2.2.4 with the –very-sensitive parameter, Duplicate reads were marked and removed with picard tools version 1.118, Peaks for ATAC-seq samples were called with MACS2 version 2.1.1.20160309 using the “–nomodel” and “–extsize 147” parameters
column20: CeMM Research Center for Molecular Medicine of the Austrian Academy of Sciences
column33: ATAC-seq on PBMCs from patient CLL5 on day 30 of ibrutinib treatment, Bcell cells
column47: Processed data files in bigWig format contain chromatin accessibility profiles and narrowPeak files contain peak calls for each sample
column48: T cell (CD3+), total B cell (CD19+, CD20+), naive B cell (CD27-, IgD+), natural effector B cell (CD27+, IgD+), and memory B cell (CD27+, IgD-).

column16: Base calls provided by the Illumina Realtime Analysis software were converted into BAM format using Illumina2bam and demultiplexed using BamIndexDecoder (https://github.com/wtsi-npg/illumina2bam), Sequenced reads were trimmed for adaptor sequences, Reads were mapped to hg19 whole genome using bowtie2 v2.2.4 with the –very-sensitive parameter, Duplicate reads were marked and removed with picard tools version 1.118, Peaks for ATAC-seq samples were called with MACS2 version 2.1.1.20160309 using the “–nomodel” and “–extsize 147” parameters
column20: CeMM Research Center for Molecular Medicine of the Austrian Academy of Sciences
column33: ATAC-seq on PBMCs from patient CLL5 on day 3 of ibrutinib treatment, CD4 cells
column47: Processed data files in bigWig format contain chromatin accessibility profiles and narrowPeak files contain peak calls for each sample

column2: ATAC-seq on PBMCs from patient CLL5 on day 3 of ibrutinib treatment, CD4 cells
column9: PBMCs_CLL patient_day 3 of ibrutinib treatment_CD4 cells
column12: All patients were diagnosed and treated and diagnosed according to the revised guidelines of the International Workshop Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia/National Cancer Institute. Patients were recruited through clinical trial NCT01804686, aimed at studying the long-term effect of PCI-32765 (ibrutinib) and reflect the clinical and biological heterogeneity of the disease. The study was approved by the ethics committees of the contributing institutions (Semmelweis University and Medical University of Vienna). Informed consent was obtained from all participants.
column14: Chromatin accessibility mapping was performed using the ATAC-seq method as previously described (Corces et al, Nature Genetics, 2016), with minor adaptations. In each experiment, a maximum of 50,000 sorted cells were pelleted by centrifuging for 5 min at 4 °C at 300 x g. After centrifugation, the pellet was carefully resuspended in the transposase reaction mix (12.5 µl 2xTD buffer, 2 µl TDE1 (Illumina) and 10.25 µl nuclease-free water, 0.25 µl 5% Digitonin (Sigma)) for 30 min at 37 °C. Following DNA purification with the MinElute kit eluting in 11 µl, 1 µl of the eluted DNA was used in a quantitative PCR (qPCR) reaction to estimate the optimum number of amplification cycles. Library amplification was followed by SPRI size selection to exclude fragments larger than 1,200 bp. DNA concentration was measured with a Qubit fluorometer (Life Technologies). Library amplification was performed using custom Nextera primers (Buenrostro et al, Nature Methods 2013). The libraries were sequenced by the Biomedical Sequencing Facility at CeMM using the Illumina HiSeq 4000 platform and the 50-bp single-end configuration.

The study was approved by the ethics committees of the contributing institutions (Semmelweis University and Medical University of Vienna). Informed consent was obtained from all participants.
column14: Chromatin accessibility mapping was performed using the ATAC-seq method as previously described (Corces et al, Nature Genetics, 2016), with minor adaptations. In each experiment, a maximum of 50,000 sorted cells were pelleted by centrifuging for 5 min at 4 °C at 300 x g. After centrifugation, the pellet was carefully resuspended in the transposase reaction mix (12.5 µl 2xTD buffer, 2 µl TDE1 (Illumina) and 10.25 µl nuclease-free water, 0.25 µl 5% Digitonin (Sigma)) for 30 min at 37 °C. Following DNA purification with the MinElute kit eluting in 11 µl, 1 µl of the eluted DNA was used in a quantitative PCR (qPCR) reaction to estimate the optimum number of amplification cycles. Library amplification was followed by SPRI size selection to exclude fragments larger than 1,200 bp. DNA concentration was measured with a Qubit fluorometer (Life Technologies). Library amplification was performed using custom Nextera primers (Buenrostro et al, Nature Methods 2013). The libraries were sequenced by the Biomedical Sequencing Facility at CeMM using the Illumina HiSeq 4000 platform and the 50-bp single-end configuration.
column15: ATAC-seq on PBMCs from patient CLL5 on day 0 of ibrutinib treatment, CD8 cells, ATAC-seq_CLL5_0d_CD8
column16: Base calls provided by the Illumina Realtime Analysis software were converted into BAM format using Illumina2bam and demultiplexed using BamIndexDecoder (https://github.com/wtsi-npg/illumina2bam), Sequenced reads were trimmed for adaptor sequences, Reads were mapped to hg19 whole genome using bowtie2 v2.2.4 with the –very-sensitive parameter, Duplicate reads were marked and removed with picard tools version 1.118, Peaks for ATAC-seq samples were called with MACS2 version 2.1.1.20160309 using the “–nomodel” and “–extsize 147” parameters
column20: CeMM Research Center for Molecular Medicine of the Austrian Academy of Sciences
column33: ATAC-seq on PBMCs from patient CLL5 on day 0 of ibrutinib treatment, CD8 cells
column47: Processed data files in bigWig format contain chromatin accessibility profiles and narrowPeak files contain peak calls for each sample
column48: T cell (CD3+), total B cell (CD19+, CD20+), naive B cell (CD27-, IgD+), natural effector B cell (CD27+, IgD+), and memory B cell (CD27+, IgD-).

column16: Base calls provided by the Illumina Realtime Analysis software were converted into BAM format using Illumina2bam and demultiplexed using BamIndexDecoder (https://github.com/wtsi-npg/illumina2bam), Sequenced reads were trimmed for adaptor sequences, Reads were mapped to hg19 whole genome using bowtie2 v2.2.4 with the –very-sensitive parameter, Duplicate reads were marked and removed with picard tools version 1.118, Peaks for ATAC-seq samples were called with MACS2 version 2.1.1.20160309 using the “–nomodel” and “–extsize 147” parameters
column20: CeMM Research Center for Molecular Medicine of the Austrian Academy of Sciences
column33: ATAC-seq on PBMCs from patient CLL5 on day 30 of ibrutinib treatment, CD8 cells
column47: Processed data files in bigWig format contain chromatin accessibility profiles and narrowPeak files contain peak calls for each sample

column2: ATAC-seq on PBMCs from patient CLL5 on day 150 of ibrutinib treatment, CD8 cells
column9: PBMCs_CLL patient_day 150 of ibrutinib treatment_CD8 cells
column12: All patients were diagnosed and treated and diagnosed according to the revised guidelines of the International Workshop Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia/National Cancer Institute. Patients were recruited through clinical trial NCT01804686, aimed at studying the long-term effect of PCI-32765 (ibrutinib) and reflect the clinical and biological heterogeneity of the disease. The study was approved by the ethics committees of the contributing institutions (Semmelweis University and Medical University of Vienna). Informed consent was obtained from all participants.
column14: Chromatin accessibility mapping was performed using the ATAC-seq method as previously described (Corces et al, Nature Genetics, 2016), with minor adaptations. In each experiment, a maximum of 50,000 sorted cells were pelleted by centrifuging for 5 min at 4 °C at 300 x g. After centrifugation, the pellet was carefully resuspended in the transposase reaction mix (12.5 µl 2xTD buffer, 2 µl TDE1 (Illumina) and 10.25 µl nuclease-free water, 0.25 µl 5% Digitonin (Sigma)) for 30 min at 37 °C. Following DNA purification with the MinElute kit eluting in 11 µl, 1 µl of the eluted DNA was used in a quantitative PCR (qPCR) reaction to estimate the optimum number of amplification cycles. Library amplification was followed by SPRI size selection to exclude fragments larger than 1,200 bp. DNA concentration was measured with a Qubit fluorometer (Life Technologies). Library amplification was performed using custom Nextera primers (Buenrostro et al, Nature Methods 2013). The libraries were sequenced by the Biomedical Sequencing Facility at CeMM using the Illumina HiSeq 4000 platform and the 50-bp single-end configuration.

The study was approved by the ethics committees of the contributing institutions (Semmelweis University and Medical University of Vienna). Informed consent was obtained from all participants.
column14: Chromatin accessibility mapping was performed using the ATAC-seq method as previously described (Corces et al, Nature Genetics, 2016), with minor adaptations. In each experiment, a maximum of 50,000 sorted cells were pelleted by centrifuging for 5 min at 4 °C at 300 x g. After centrifugation, the pellet was carefully resuspended in the transposase reaction mix (12.5 µl 2xTD buffer, 2 µl TDE1 (Illumina) and 10.25 µl nuclease-free water, 0.25 µl 5% Digitonin (Sigma)) for 30 min at 37 °C. Following DNA purification with the MinElute kit eluting in 11 µl, 1 µl of the eluted DNA was used in a quantitative PCR (qPCR) reaction to estimate the optimum number of amplification cycles. Library amplification was followed by SPRI size selection to exclude fragments larger than 1,200 bp. DNA concentration was measured with a Qubit fluorometer (Life Technologies). Library amplification was performed using custom Nextera primers (Buenrostro et al, Nature Methods 2013). The libraries were sequenced by the Biomedical Sequencing Facility at CeMM using the Illumina HiSeq 4000 platform and the 50-bp single-end configuration.
column15: ATAC-seq on PBMCs from patient CLL5 on day 3 of ibrutinib treatment, CLL cells, ATAC-seq_CLL5_3d_CLL
column16: Base calls provided by the Illumina Realtime Analysis software were converted into BAM format using Illumina2bam and demultiplexed using BamIndexDecoder (https://github.com/wtsi-npg/illumina2bam), Sequenced reads were trimmed for adaptor sequences, Reads were mapped to hg19 whole genome using bowtie2 v2.2.4 with the –very-sensitive parameter, Duplicate reads were marked and removed with picard tools version 1.118, Peaks for ATAC-seq samples were called with MACS2 version 2.1.1.20160309 using the “–nomodel” and “–extsize 147” parameters
column20: CeMM Research Center for Molecular Medicine of the Austrian Academy of Sciences
column33: ATAC-seq on PBMCs from patient CLL5 on day 3 of ibrutinib treatment, CLL cells
column47: Processed data files in bigWig format contain chromatin accessibility profiles and narrowPeak files contain peak calls for each sample
column48: T cell (CD3+), total B cell (CD19+, CD20+), naive B cell (CD27-, IgD+), natural effector B cell (CD27+, IgD+), and memory B cell (CD27+, IgD-).

column16: Base calls provided by the Illumina Realtime Analysis software were converted into BAM format using Illumina2bam and demultiplexed using BamIndexDecoder (https://github.com/wtsi-npg/illumina2bam), Sequenced reads were trimmed for adaptor sequences, Reads were mapped to hg19 whole genome using bowtie2 v2.2.4 with the –very-sensitive parameter, Duplicate reads were marked and removed with picard tools version 1.118, Peaks for ATAC-seq samples were called with MACS2 version 2.1.1.20160309 using the “–nomodel” and “–extsize 147” parameters

column2: ATAC-seq on PBMCs from patient CLL5 on day 0 of ibrutinib treatment, Mono cells
column9: PBMCs_CLL patient_day 0 of ibrutinib treatment_Mono cells
column12: All patients were diagnosed and treated and diagnosed according to the revised guidelines of the International Workshop Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia/National Cancer Institute. Patients were recruited through clinical trial NCT01804686, aimed at studying the long-term effect of PCI-32765 (ibrutinib) and reflect the clinical and biological heterogeneity of the disease. The study was approved by the ethics committees of the contributing institutions (Semmelweis University and Medical University of Vienna). Informed consent was obtained from all participants.
column14: Chromatin accessibility mapping was performed using the ATAC-seq method as previously described (Corces et al, Nature Genetics, 2016), with minor adaptations. In each experiment, a maximum of 50,000 sorted cells were pelleted by centrifuging for 5 min at 4 °C at 300 x g. After centrifugation, the pellet was carefully resuspended in the transposase reaction mix (12.5 µl 2xTD buffer, 2 µl TDE1 (Illumina) and 10.25 µl nuclease-free water, 0.25 µl 5% Digitonin (Sigma)) for 30 min at 37 °C. Following DNA purification with the MinElute kit eluting in 11 µl, 1 µl of the eluted DNA was used in a quantitative PCR (qPCR) reaction to estimate the optimum number of amplification cycles. Library amplification was followed by SPRI size selection to exclude fragments larger than 1,200 bp. DNA concentration was measured with a Qubit fluorometer (Life Technologies). Library amplification was performed using custom Nextera primers (Buenrostro et al, Nature Methods 2013). The libraries were sequenced by the Biomedical Sequencing Facility at CeMM using the Illumina HiSeq 4000 platform and the 50-bp single-end configuration.

column14: Chromatin accessibility mapping was performed using the ATAC-seq method as previously described (Corces et al, Nature Genetics, 2016), with minor adaptations. In each experiment, a maximum of 50,000 sorted cells were pelleted by centrifuging for 5 min at 4 °C at 300 x g. After centrifugation, the pellet was carefully resuspended in the transposase reaction mix (12.5 µl 2xTD buffer, 2 µl TDE1 (Illumina) and 10.25 µl nuclease-free water, 0.25 µl 5% Digitonin (Sigma)) for 30 min at 37 °C. Following DNA purification with the MinElute kit eluting in 11 µl, 1 µl of the eluted DNA was used in a quantitative PCR (qPCR) reaction to estimate the optimum number of amplification cycles. Library amplification was followed by SPRI size selection to exclude fragments larger than 1,200 bp. DNA concentration was measured with a Qubit fluorometer (Life Technologies). Library amplification was performed using custom Nextera primers (Buenrostro et al, Nature Methods 2013). The libraries were sequenced by the Biomedical Sequencing Facility at CeMM using the Illumina HiSeq 4000 platform and the 50-bp single-end configuration.
column15: ATAC-seq on PBMCs from patient CLL5 on day 0 of ibrutinib treatment, NK cells, ATAC-seq_CLL5_0d_NK
column16: Base calls provided by the Illumina Realtime Analysis software were converted into BAM format using Illumina2bam and demultiplexed using BamIndexDecoder (https://github.com/wtsi-npg/illumina2bam), Sequenced reads were trimmed for adaptor sequences, Reads were mapped to hg19 whole genome using bowtie2 v2.2.4 with the –very-sensitive parameter, Duplicate reads were marked and removed with picard tools version 1.118, Peaks for ATAC-seq samples were called with MACS2 version 2.1.1.20160309 using the “–nomodel” and “–extsize 147” parameters
column20: CeMM Research Center for Molecular Medicine of the Austrian Academy of Sciences
column33: ATAC-seq on PBMCs from patient CLL5 on day 0 of ibrutinib treatment, NK cells
column47: Processed data files in bigWig format contain chromatin accessibility profiles and narrowPeak files contain peak calls for each sample
column48: T cell (CD3+), total B cell (CD19+, CD20+), naive B cell (CD27-, IgD+), natural effector B cell (CD27+, IgD+), and memory B cell (CD27+, IgD-).

column20: CeMM Research Center for Molecular Medicine of the Austrian Academy of Sciences
column33: ATAC-seq on PBMCs from patient CLL5 on day 30 of ibrutinib treatment, NK cells
column47: Processed data files in bigWig format contain chromatin accessibility profiles and narrowPeak files contain peak calls for each sample
column48: T cell (CD3+), total B cell (CD19+, CD20+), naive B cell (CD27-, IgD+), natural effector B cell (CD27+, IgD+), and memory B cell (CD27+, IgD-).

column2: ATAC-seq on PBMCs from patient CLL6 on day 120 of ibrutinib treatment, Bcell cells
column9: PBMCs_CLL patient_day 120 of ibrutinib treatment_Bcell cells
column12: All patients were diagnosed and treated and diagnosed according to the revised guidelines of the International Workshop Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia/National Cancer Institute. Patients were recruited through clinical trial NCT01804686, aimed at studying the long-term effect of PCI-32765 (ibrutinib) and reflect the clinical and biological heterogeneity of the disease. The study was approved by the ethics committees of the contributing institutions (Semmelweis University and Medical University of Vienna). Informed consent was obtained from all participants.
column14: Chromatin accessibility mapping was performed using the ATAC-seq method as previously described (Corces et al, Nature Genetics, 2016), with minor adaptations. In each experiment, a maximum of 50,000 sorted cells were pelleted by centrifuging for 5 min at 4 °C at 300 x g. After centrifugation, the pellet was carefully resuspended in the transposase reaction mix (12.5 µl 2xTD buffer, 2 µl TDE1 (Illumina) and 10.25 µl nuclease-free water, 0.25 µl 5% Digitonin (Sigma)) for 30 min at 37 °C. Following DNA purification with the MinElute kit eluting in 11 µl, 1 µl of the eluted DNA was used in a quantitative PCR (qPCR) reaction to estimate the optimum number of amplification cycles. Library amplification was followed by SPRI size selection to exclude fragments larger than 1,200 bp. DNA concentration was measured with a Qubit fluorometer (Life Technologies). Library amplification was performed using custom Nextera primers (Buenrostro et al, Nature Methods 2013). The libraries were sequenced by the Biomedical Sequencing Facility at CeMM using the Illumina HiSeq 4000 platform and the 50-bp single-end configuration.

column14: Chromatin accessibility mapping was performed using the ATAC-seq method as previously described (Corces et al, Nature Genetics, 2016), with minor adaptations. In each experiment, a maximum of 50,000 sorted cells were pelleted by centrifuging for 5 min at 4 °C at 300 x g. After centrifugation, the pellet was carefully resuspended in the transposase reaction mix (12.5 µl 2xTD buffer, 2 µl TDE1 (Illumina) and 10.25 µl nuclease-free water, 0.25 µl 5% Digitonin (Sigma)) for 30 min at 37 °C. Following DNA purification with the MinElute kit eluting in 11 µl, 1 µl of the eluted DNA was used in a quantitative PCR (qPCR) reaction to estimate the optimum number of amplification cycles. Library amplification was followed by SPRI size selection to exclude fragments larger than 1,200 bp. DNA concentration was measured with a Qubit fluorometer (Life Technologies). Library amplification was performed using custom Nextera primers (Buenrostro et al, Nature Methods 2013). The libraries were sequenced by the Biomedical Sequencing Facility at CeMM using the Illumina HiSeq 4000 platform and the 50-bp single-end configuration.
column15: ATAC-seq on PBMCs from patient CLL6 on day 0 of ibrutinib treatment, CD8 cells, ATAC-seq_CLL6_0d_CD8
column16: Base calls provided by the Illumina Realtime Analysis software were converted into BAM format using Illumina2bam and demultiplexed using BamIndexDecoder (https://github.com/wtsi-npg/illumina2bam), Sequenced reads were trimmed for adaptor sequences, Reads were mapped to hg19 whole genome using bowtie2 v2.2.4 with the –very-sensitive parameter, Duplicate reads were marked and removed with picard tools version 1.118, Peaks for ATAC-seq samples were called with MACS2 version 2.1.1.20160309 using the “–nomodel” and “–extsize 147” parameters
column20: CeMM Research Center for Molecular Medicine of the Austrian Academy of Sciences
column33: ATAC-seq on PBMCs from patient CLL6 on day 0 of ibrutinib treatment, CD8 cells
column47: Processed data files in bigWig format contain chromatin accessibility profiles and narrowPeak files contain peak calls for each sample

column16: Base calls provided by the Illumina Realtime Analysis software were converted into BAM format using Illumina2bam and demultiplexed using BamIndexDecoder (https://github.com/wtsi-npg/illumina2bam), Sequenced reads were trimmed for adaptor sequences, Reads were mapped to hg19 whole genome using bowtie2 v2.2.4 with the –very-sensitive parameter, Duplicate reads were marked and removed with picard tools version 1.118, Peaks for ATAC-seq samples were called with MACS2 version 2.1.1.20160309 using the “–nomodel” and “–extsize 147” parameters

column2: ATAC-seq on PBMCs from patient CLL6 on day 030 of ibrutinib treatment, CLL cells
column9: PBMCs_CLL patient_day 030 of ibrutinib treatment_CLL cells
column12: All patients were diagnosed and treated and diagnosed according to the revised guidelines of the International Workshop Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia/National Cancer Institute. Patients were recruited through clinical trial NCT01804686, aimed at studying the long-term effect of PCI-32765 (ibrutinib) and reflect the clinical and biological heterogeneity of the disease. The study was approved by the ethics committees of the contributing institutions (Semmelweis University and Medical University of Vienna). Informed consent was obtained from all participants.
column14: Chromatin accessibility mapping was performed using the ATAC-seq method as previously described (Corces et al, Nature Genetics, 2016), with minor adaptations. In each experiment, a maximum of 50,000 sorted cells were pelleted by centrifuging for 5 min at 4 °C at 300 x g. After centrifugation, the pellet was carefully resuspended in the transposase reaction mix (12.5 µl 2xTD buffer, 2 µl TDE1 (Illumina) and 10.25 µl nuclease-free water, 0.25 µl 5% Digitonin (Sigma)) for 30 min at 37 °C. Following DNA purification with the MinElute kit eluting in 11 µl, 1 µl of the eluted DNA was used in a quantitative PCR (qPCR) reaction to estimate the optimum number of amplification cycles. Library amplification was followed by SPRI size selection to exclude fragments larger than 1,200 bp. DNA concentration was measured with a Qubit fluorometer (Life Technologies). Library amplification was performed using custom Nextera primers (Buenrostro et al, Nature Methods 2013). The libraries were sequenced by the Biomedical Sequencing Facility at CeMM using the Illumina HiSeq 4000 platform and the 50-bp single-end configuration.

The study was approved by the ethics committees of the contributing institutions (Semmelweis University and Medical University of Vienna). Informed consent was obtained from all participants.
column14: Chromatin accessibility mapping was performed using the ATAC-seq method as previously described (Corces et al, Nature Genetics, 2016), with minor adaptations. In each experiment, a maximum of 50,000 sorted cells were pelleted by centrifuging for 5 min at 4 °C at 300 x g. After centrifugation, the pellet was carefully resuspended in the transposase reaction mix (12.5 µl 2xTD buffer, 2 µl TDE1 (Illumina) and 10.25 µl nuclease-free water, 0.25 µl 5% Digitonin (Sigma)) for 30 min at 37 °C. Following DNA purification with the MinElute kit eluting in 11 µl, 1 µl of the eluted DNA was used in a quantitative PCR (qPCR) reaction to estimate the optimum number of amplification cycles. Library amplification was followed by SPRI size selection to exclude fragments larger than 1,200 bp. DNA concentration was measured with a Qubit fluorometer (Life Technologies). Library amplification was performed using custom Nextera primers (Buenrostro et al, Nature Methods 2013). The libraries were sequenced by the Biomedical Sequencing Facility at CeMM using the Illumina HiSeq 4000 platform and the 50-bp single-end configuration.
column15: ATAC-seq on PBMCs from patient CLL6 on day 120 of ibrutinib treatment, Mono cells, ATAC-seq_CLL6_120d_Mono
column16: Base calls provided by the Illumina Realtime Analysis software were converted into BAM format using Illumina2bam and demultiplexed using BamIndexDecoder (https://github.com/wtsi-npg/illumina2bam), Sequenced reads were trimmed for adaptor sequences, Reads were mapped to hg19 whole genome using bowtie2 v2.2.4 with the –very-sensitive parameter, Duplicate reads were marked and removed with picard tools version 1.118, Peaks for ATAC-seq samples were called with MACS2 version 2.1.1.20160309 using the “–nomodel” and “–extsize 147” parameters
column20: CeMM Research Center for Molecular Medicine of the Austrian Academy of Sciences
column33: ATAC-seq on PBMCs from patient CLL6 on day 120 of ibrutinib treatment, Mono cells
column47: Processed data files in bigWig format contain chromatin accessibility profiles and narrowPeak files contain peak calls for each sample
column48: T cell (CD3+), total B cell (CD19+, CD20+), naive B cell (CD27-, IgD+), natural effector B cell (CD27+, IgD+), and memory B cell (CD27+, IgD-).

column16: Base calls provided by the Illumina Realtime Analysis software were converted into BAM format using Illumina2bam and demultiplexed using BamIndexDecoder (https://github.com/wtsi-npg/illumina2bam), Sequenced reads were trimmed for adaptor sequences, Reads were mapped to hg19 whole genome using bowtie2 v2.2.4 with the –very-sensitive parameter, Duplicate reads were marked and removed with picard tools version 1.118, Peaks for ATAC-seq samples were called with MACS2 version 2.1.1.20160309 using the “–nomodel” and “–extsize 147” parameters
column20: CeMM Research Center for Molecular Medicine of the Austrian Academy of Sciences

column2: ATAC-seq on PBMCs from patient CLL7 on day 150 of ibrutinib treatment, Bcell cells
column9: PBMCs_CLL patient_day 150 of ibrutinib treatment_Bcell cells
column12: All patients were diagnosed and treated and diagnosed according to the revised guidelines of the International Workshop Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia/National Cancer Institute. Patients were recruited through clinical trial NCT01804686, aimed at studying the long-term effect of PCI-32765 (ibrutinib) and reflect the clinical and biological heterogeneity of the disease. The study was approved by the ethics committees of the contributing institutions (Semmelweis University and Medical University of Vienna). Informed consent was obtained from all participants.
column14: Chromatin accessibility mapping was performed using the ATAC-seq method as previously described (Corces et al, Nature Genetics, 2016), with minor adaptations. In each experiment, a maximum of 50,000 sorted cells were pelleted by centrifuging for 5 min at 4 °C at 300 x g. After centrifugation, the pellet was carefully resuspended in the transposase reaction mix (12.5 µl 2xTD buffer, 2 µl TDE1 (Illumina) and 10.25 µl nuclease-free water, 0.25 µl 5% Digitonin (Sigma)) for 30 min at 37 °C. Following DNA purification with the MinElute kit eluting in 11 µl, 1 µl of the eluted DNA was used in a quantitative PCR (qPCR) reaction to estimate the optimum number of amplification cycles. Library amplification was followed by SPRI size selection to exclude fragments larger than 1,200 bp. DNA concentration was measured with a Qubit fluorometer (Life Technologies). Library amplification was performed using custom Nextera primers (Buenrostro et al, Nature Methods 2013). The libraries were sequenced by the Biomedical Sequencing Facility at CeMM using the Illumina HiSeq 4000 platform and the 50-bp single-end configuration.

The study was approved by the ethics committees of the contributing institutions (Semmelweis University and Medical University of Vienna). Informed consent was obtained from all participants.
column14: Chromatin accessibility mapping was performed using the ATAC-seq method as previously described (Corces et al, Nature Genetics, 2016), with minor adaptations. In each experiment, a maximum of 50,000 sorted cells were pelleted by centrifuging for 5 min at 4 °C at 300 x g. After centrifugation, the pellet was carefully resuspended in the transposase reaction mix (12.5 µl 2xTD buffer, 2 µl TDE1 (Illumina) and 10.25 µl nuclease-free water, 0.25 µl 5% Digitonin (Sigma)) for 30 min at 37 °C. Following DNA purification with the MinElute kit eluting in 11 µl, 1 µl of the eluted DNA was used in a quantitative PCR (qPCR) reaction to estimate the optimum number of amplification cycles. Library amplification was followed by SPRI size selection to exclude fragments larger than 1,200 bp. DNA concentration was measured with a Qubit fluorometer (Life Technologies). Library amplification was performed using custom Nextera primers (Buenrostro et al, Nature Methods 2013). The libraries were sequenced by the Biomedical Sequencing Facility at CeMM using the Illumina HiSeq 4000 platform and the 50-bp single-end configuration.
column15: ATAC-seq on PBMCs from patient CLL7 on day 30 of ibrutinib treatment, CD4 cells, ATAC-seq_CLL7_30d_CD4
column16: Base calls provided by the Illumina Realtime Analysis software were converted into BAM format using Illumina2bam and demultiplexed using BamIndexDecoder (https://github.com/wtsi-npg/illumina2bam), Sequenced reads were trimmed for adaptor sequences, Reads were mapped to hg19 whole genome using bowtie2 v2.2.4 with the –very-sensitive parameter, Duplicate reads were marked and removed with picard tools version 1.118, Peaks for ATAC-seq samples were called with MACS2 version 2.1.1.20160309 using the “–nomodel” and “–extsize 147” parameters
column20: CeMM Research Center for Molecular Medicine of the Austrian Academy of Sciences
column33: ATAC-seq on PBMCs from patient CLL7 on day 30 of ibrutinib treatment, CD4 cells
column47: Processed data files in bigWig format contain chromatin accessibility profiles and narrowPeak files contain peak calls for each sample
column48: T cell (CD3+), total B cell (CD19+, CD20+), naive B cell (CD27-, IgD+), natural effector B cell (CD27+, IgD+), and memory B cell (CD27+, IgD-).

column16: Base calls provided by the Illumina Realtime Analysis software were converted into BAM format using Illumina2bam and demultiplexed using BamIndexDecoder (https://github.com/wtsi-npg/illumina2bam), Sequenced reads were trimmed for adaptor sequences, Reads were mapped to hg19 whole genome using bowtie2 v2.2.4 with the –very-sensitive parameter, Duplicate reads were marked and removed with picard tools version 1.118, Peaks for ATAC-seq samples were called with MACS2 version 2.1.1.20160309 using the “–nomodel” and “–extsize 147” parameters

column2: ATAC-seq on PBMCs from patient CLL7 on day 8 of ibrutinib treatment, CD8 cells
column9: PBMCs_CLL patient_day 8 of ibrutinib treatment_CD8 cells
column12: All patients were diagnosed and treated and diagnosed according to the revised guidelines of the International Workshop Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia/National Cancer Institute. Patients were recruited through clinical trial NCT01804686, aimed at studying the long-term effect of PCI-32765 (ibrutinib) and reflect the clinical and biological heterogeneity of the disease. The study was approved by the ethics committees of the contributing institutions (Semmelweis University and Medical University of Vienna). Informed consent was obtained from all participants.
column14: Chromatin accessibility mapping was performed using the ATAC-seq method as previously described (Corces et al, Nature Genetics, 2016), with minor adaptations. In each experiment, a maximum of 50,000 sorted cells were pelleted by centrifuging for 5 min at 4 °C at 300 x g. After centrifugation, the pellet was carefully resuspended in the transposase reaction mix (12.5 µl 2xTD buffer, 2 µl TDE1 (Illumina) and 10.25 µl nuclease-free water, 0.25 µl 5% Digitonin (Sigma)) for 30 min at 37 °C. Following DNA purification with the MinElute kit eluting in 11 µl, 1 µl of the eluted DNA was used in a quantitative PCR (qPCR) reaction to estimate the optimum number of amplification cycles. Library amplification was followed by SPRI size selection to exclude fragments larger than 1,200 bp. DNA concentration was measured with a Qubit fluorometer (Life Technologies). Library amplification was performed using custom Nextera primers (Buenrostro et al, Nature Methods 2013). The libraries were sequenced by the Biomedical Sequencing Facility at CeMM using the Illumina HiSeq 4000 platform and the 50-bp single-end configuration.

The study was approved by the ethics committees of the contributing institutions (Semmelweis University and Medical University of Vienna). Informed consent was obtained from all participants.
column14: Chromatin accessibility mapping was performed using the ATAC-seq method as previously described (Corces et al, Nature Genetics, 2016), with minor adaptations. In each experiment, a maximum of 50,000 sorted cells were pelleted by centrifuging for 5 min at 4 °C at 300 x g. After centrifugation, the pellet was carefully resuspended in the transposase reaction mix (12.5 µl 2xTD buffer, 2 µl TDE1 (Illumina) and 10.25 µl nuclease-free water, 0.25 µl 5% Digitonin (Sigma)) for 30 min at 37 °C. Following DNA purification with the MinElute kit eluting in 11 µl, 1 µl of the eluted DNA was used in a quantitative PCR (qPCR) reaction to estimate the optimum number of amplification cycles. Library amplification was followed by SPRI size selection to exclude fragments larger than 1,200 bp. DNA concentration was measured with a Qubit fluorometer (Life Technologies). Library amplification was performed using custom Nextera primers (Buenrostro et al, Nature Methods 2013). The libraries were sequenced by the Biomedical Sequencing Facility at CeMM using the Illumina HiSeq 4000 platform and the 50-bp single-end configuration.
column15: ATAC-seq on PBMCs from patient CLL7 on day 3 of ibrutinib treatment, CLL cells, ATAC-seq_CLL7_3d_CLL
column16: Base calls provided by the Illumina Realtime Analysis software were converted into BAM format using Illumina2bam and demultiplexed using BamIndexDecoder (https://github.com/wtsi-npg/illumina2bam), Sequenced reads were trimmed for adaptor sequences, Reads were mapped to hg19 whole genome using bowtie2 v2.2.4 with the –very-sensitive parameter, Duplicate reads were marked and removed with picard tools version 1.118, Peaks for ATAC-seq samples were called with MACS2 version 2.1.1.20160309 using the “–nomodel” and “–extsize 147” parameters
column20: CeMM Research Center for Molecular Medicine of the Austrian Academy of Sciences
column33: ATAC-seq on PBMCs from patient CLL7 on day 3 of ibrutinib treatment, CLL cells
column47: Processed data files in bigWig format contain chromatin accessibility profiles and narrowPeak files contain peak calls for each sample
column48: T cell (CD3+), total B cell (CD19+, CD20+), naive B cell (CD27-, IgD+), natural effector B cell (CD27+, IgD+), and memory B cell (CD27+, IgD-).

column16: Base calls provided by the Illumina Realtime Analysis software were converted into BAM format using Illumina2bam and demultiplexed using BamIndexDecoder (https://github.com/wtsi-npg/illumina2bam), Sequenced reads were trimmed for adaptor sequences, Reads were mapped to hg19 whole genome using bowtie2 v2.2.4 with the –very-sensitive parameter, Duplicate reads were marked and removed with picard tools version 1.118, Peaks for ATAC-seq samples were called with MACS2 version 2.1.1.20160309 using the “–nomodel” and “–extsize 147” parameters
column20: CeMM Research Center for Molecular Medicine of the Austrian Academy of Sciences
column33: ATAC-seq on PBMCs from patient CLL7 on day 30 of ibrutinib treatment, NK cells
column47: Processed data files in bigWig format contain chromatin accessibility profiles and narrowPeak files contain peak calls for each sample

column2: ATAC-seq on PBMCs from patient CLL7 on day 150 of ibrutinib treatment, NK cells
column9: PBMCs_CLL patient_day 150 of ibrutinib treatment_NK cells
column12: All patients were diagnosed and treated and diagnosed according to the revised guidelines of the International Workshop Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia/National Cancer Institute. Patients were recruited through clinical trial NCT01804686, aimed at studying the long-term effect of PCI-32765 (ibrutinib) and reflect the clinical and biological heterogeneity of the disease. The study was approved by the ethics committees of the contributing institutions (Semmelweis University and Medical University of Vienna). Informed consent was obtained from all participants.
column14: Chromatin accessibility mapping was performed using the ATAC-seq method as previously described (Corces et al, Nature Genetics, 2016), with minor adaptations. In each experiment, a maximum of 50,000 sorted cells were pelleted by centrifuging for 5 min at 4 °C at 300 x g. After centrifugation, the pellet was carefully resuspended in the transposase reaction mix (12.5 µl 2xTD buffer, 2 µl TDE1 (Illumina) and 10.25 µl nuclease-free water, 0.25 µl 5% Digitonin (Sigma)) for 30 min at 37 °C. Following DNA purification with the MinElute kit eluting in 11 µl, 1 µl of the eluted DNA was used in a quantitative PCR (qPCR) reaction to estimate the optimum number of amplification cycles. Library amplification was followed by SPRI size selection to exclude fragments larger than 1,200 bp. DNA concentration was measured with a Qubit fluorometer (Life Technologies). Library amplification was performed using custom Nextera primers (Buenrostro et al, Nature Methods 2013). The libraries were sequenced by the Biomedical Sequencing Facility at CeMM using the Illumina HiSeq 4000 platform and the 50-bp single-end configuration.

The study was approved by the ethics committees of the contributing institutions (Semmelweis University and Medical University of Vienna). Informed consent was obtained from all participants.
column14: Chromatin accessibility mapping was performed using the ATAC-seq method as previously described (Corces et al, Nature Genetics, 2016), with minor adaptations. In each experiment, a maximum of 50,000 sorted cells were pelleted by centrifuging for 5 min at 4 °C at 300 x g. After centrifugation, the pellet was carefully resuspended in the transposase reaction mix (12.5 µl 2xTD buffer, 2 µl TDE1 (Illumina) and 10.25 µl nuclease-free water, 0.25 µl 5% Digitonin (Sigma)) for 30 min at 37 °C. Following DNA purification with the MinElute kit eluting in 11 µl, 1 µl of the eluted DNA was used in a quantitative PCR (qPCR) reaction to estimate the optimum number of amplification cycles. Library amplification was followed by SPRI size selection to exclude fragments larger than 1,200 bp. DNA concentration was measured with a Qubit fluorometer (Life Technologies). Library amplification was performed using custom Nextera primers (Buenrostro et al, Nature Methods 2013). The libraries were sequenced by the Biomedical Sequencing Facility at CeMM using the Illumina HiSeq 4000 platform and the 50-bp single-end configuration.
column15: ATAC-seq on PBMCs from patient CLL8 on day 030 of ibrutinib treatment, CD8 cells, ATAC-seq_CLL8_030d_CD8
column16: Base calls provided by the Illumina Realtime Analysis software were converted into BAM format using Illumina2bam and demultiplexed using BamIndexDecoder (https://github.com/wtsi-npg/illumina2bam), Sequenced reads were trimmed for adaptor sequences, Reads were mapped to hg19 whole genome using bowtie2 v2.2.4 with the –very-sensitive parameter, Duplicate reads were marked and removed with picard tools version 1.118, Peaks for ATAC-seq samples were called with MACS2 version 2.1.1.20160309 using the “–nomodel” and “–extsize 147” parameters
column20: CeMM Research Center for Molecular Medicine of the Austrian Academy of Sciences
column33: ATAC-seq on PBMCs from patient CLL8 on day 030 of ibrutinib treatment, CD8 cells
column47: Processed data files in bigWig format contain chromatin accessibility profiles and narrowPeak files contain peak calls for each sample
column48: T cell (CD3+), total B cell (CD19+, CD20+), naive B cell (CD27-, IgD+), natural effector B cell (CD27+, IgD+), and memory B cell (CD27+, IgD-).

column16: Base calls provided by the Illumina Realtime Analysis software were converted into BAM format using Illumina2bam and demultiplexed using BamIndexDecoder (https://github.com/wtsi-npg/illumina2bam), Sequenced reads were trimmed for adaptor sequences, Reads were mapped to hg19 whole genome using bowtie2 v2.2.4 with the –very-sensitive parameter, Duplicate reads were marked and removed with picard tools version 1.118, Peaks for ATAC-seq samples were called with MACS2 version 2.1.1.20160309 using the “–nomodel” and “–extsize 147” parameters

column2: ATAC-seq on PBMCs from patient CLL8 on day 3 of ibrutinib treatment, Mono cells
column9: PBMCs_CLL patient_day 3 of ibrutinib treatment_Mono cells
column12: All patients were diagnosed and treated and diagnosed according to the revised guidelines of the International Workshop Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia/National Cancer Institute. Patients were recruited through clinical trial NCT01804686, aimed at studying the long-term effect of PCI-32765 (ibrutinib) and reflect the clinical and biological heterogeneity of the disease. The study was approved by the ethics committees of the contributing institutions (Semmelweis University and Medical University of Vienna). Informed consent was obtained from all participants.
column14: Chromatin accessibility mapping was performed using the ATAC-seq method as previously described (Corces et al, Nature Genetics, 2016), with minor adaptations. In each experiment, a maximum of 50,000 sorted cells were pelleted by centrifuging for 5 min at 4 °C at 300 x g. After centrifugation, the pellet was carefully resuspended in the transposase reaction mix (12.5 µl 2xTD buffer, 2 µl TDE1 (Illumina) and 10.25 µl nuclease-free water, 0.25 µl 5% Digitonin (Sigma)) for 30 min at 37 °C. Following DNA purification with the MinElute kit eluting in 11 µl, 1 µl of the eluted DNA was used in a quantitative PCR (qPCR) reaction to estimate the optimum number of amplification cycles. Library amplification was followed by SPRI size selection to exclude fragments larger than 1,200 bp. DNA concentration was measured with a Qubit fluorometer (Life Technologies). Library amplification was performed using custom Nextera primers (Buenrostro et al, Nature Methods 2013). The libraries were sequenced by the Biomedical Sequencing Facility at CeMM using the Illumina HiSeq 4000 platform and the 50-bp single-end configuration.
